conclusion: To determine the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity, we need to analyze energy loss due to inelastic collision and air resistance.
Consider the situation without air resistance where the basketball drops from height H and rebounds to height h.
The pre-collision velocity v_i when the ball hits the ground is v_i = sqrt(2gH).
The post-collision velocity v_f when the ball leaves the ground is v_f = sqrt(2gh).
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is v_f/v_i = sqrt(h/H).
Account for air resistance where air resistance force is lambda mg with 0 < lambda < (H-h)/(H+h).
The work done by air resistance reduces kinetic energy, but given problem constraints, the ratio remains approximately the same as without air resistance.
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is approximately sqrt(h/H).
